Award.AwardTitle: Bridging the Divide: Exploring Native Approaches to Science Through Analysis of Implementation of a Complex Information Technology in Alaska Native Communities
Award.AbstractNarration: This award funds the planning and preliminary development of a research project to study implementation of cutting edge information technology, a Fab Lab, in a rural Alaska Native village in southwest Alaska, Togiak. The Bristol Bay Campus, University of Alaska Fairbanks (UAF BBC) and Alaska Federation of Natives (AFN) will partner with the Champaign Urbana Community Fab Lab and the Institute for Humanities, Arts, and Social Science (I-CHASS) of the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign (UIUC) to implement a Fab Lab in Togiak, Alaska. This project was developed in collaboration with the Alaska Federation of Natives and the village of Togiak following the very successful demonstration project, funded by NSF ASSP, that introduced the Fab Lab concept at the annual Alaska Federation of Natives Convention in Fairbanks, Alaska 2010. The AFN Convention Fab Lab was successful in demonstrating that an operational Fab Lab could be set up in Alaska and that people, once introduced to the technology in action, would see its potential and would want to be a part of Fab Lab development in the state. During the convention, forty individuals from seventeen different communities around the state signed up for information on how to bring a Fab Lab to their community. Non-scientist participants were also able to observe how the world-wide-web can be used to share ideas and work on projects together and, in doing so, build global connections and use technology to develop capacity in even the most remote location. This project has strong potential for long term economic development among a population that has some of the highest official unemployment rates in the country due to lack of opportunity in these very remote regions of the state.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project was the planning and preliminary development of a study of implementation of cutting edge information technology, a FabLab, in the rural Alaska Native village of Togiak, Alaska. There were three major goals:(1) To install a FabLab (Facility for personal fabrication, ?making?, and learning about computer based manufacturing tools such as 3D printers, laser cutters / engravers, etc.); (2)To assist local Alaska Natives in Togiak in the design, utilization and maintenance of the facilty; and (3)To study the deployment of the lab in order to better understand how such technology can be used and deployed in similar areas and demographics. The Village of Togiak, Bristol Bay Campus, University of Alaska Fairbanks, and Alaska Federation of Natives (AFN) partnered with the Champaign Urbana Community Fab Lab and the Institute for Humanities, Arts, and Social Science (I-CHASS) of the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign (UIUC).

The research focused on the intersection and interaction of Western and indigenous American perspectives on implementation of science and technology. It attempted to inquire into how Alaska Native ways of knowing refracted a technology bundle designed according to Western logic. The project sought to utilize the creative skills and knowledge of Togiak residents to guide planning for implementation of the Fab Lab and in so doing provide additional opportunities for local community members. Togiak villagers faced a number of challenges as they strive to increase benefits to low-income residents, to foster growth and job creation, provide educational and vocational opportunities to local youth, and to ensure the sustainability an isolated rural community that are threatened by out migration, high fuel costs and limited connections with other communities due to geographical isolation. The project team believed the Fab Lab was an opportunity to provide new opportunities to residents as well as address questions concerning digital divides and cultural approaches to appropriating science and technology.

The project teams worked with the Traditional Council of Tokiak to implement the Tuyuryaq FabLab. The facility was set up and used primarily by children visiting the Boys and Girls Club of Togiak, the building where it was located.  Several barriers to use of the FabLab prevented the project from reaching its full potential.  These included: (1) A delay in starting the project due to normal review and administrative procedures. During that time, some of the key individuals who advocated for the Lab at the City and Tribal

level, and would have taken key roles in implication, were no longer in those leadership positions. This turnover is typical in small communities in which there are few people to serve on boards for the community. (2) The technological capabilities of the adults in the village were limited and interfered with uptake of the lab. The team did not realize that there needed to be a more extensive introduction to computing and software and examples of how to use computers in the novel ways required for a FabLab. Though we wanted adults to use the lab, we didn?t consider how to bridge that digital gap for those with limited computer skills. (3) The distance from support resources and the remoteness of the community made it difficult to get equipment in and made servicing and problem solving difficult. Supplies were difficult to purchase and the phone and internet outages complicated matters. (4) The only facility available to house the FabLab, the Boys and Girls Club, had restrictions on adult participation, which limited usage of the FabLab.  While it served as a solid resource for school children the demographic that we had envisioned would use the FabLab was not able to enter the facility.  An alternative location was found, but problems in the community required it to be used for other purposes. (5) It was difficult to find personnel to manage the lab and instruct users.  There was a great deal of turnover due to economic demands on Togiak residents and restrictions on who could work in the Boys and Girls Club. (6) The team had hoped there would be State or private resources to continue to support the Lab. When we started this project the state was in good economic shape and private donors were available as well.  The downturn in the oil industry has changed things greatly. There are no state grants available and philanthropic funding is stretched thin.  

The Togiak School agreed to host and staff the FabLab and the facility has been moved to the school. Several teachers at the high school will be able to provide the support needed to keep the lab going and ensure that the investment in the FabLab will continue to pay off for the village.
